message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest gastric carcinoma, and the raised lesion with central ulceration on the lesser curvature of the stomach supports this diagnosis. Gland-forming cuboidal cells are typically seen in adenocarcinoma of the stomach. Neutrophilic infiltration with pit abscesses are seen in acute gastritis, foveolar and smooth muscle hyperplasia are seen in chronic gastritis, and lymphocytic aggregates with noncaseating granulomas are seen in Crohn’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristic features of the patient’s symptoms and findings suggest the most likely diagnosis is gastric adenocarcinoma. The histologic examination of a gastric biopsy specimen from the lesion will most likely show gland-forming cuboidal cells. Neutrophilic infiltration with pit abscesses suggests acute gastritis, while foveolar and smooth muscle hyperplasia suggest chronic gastritis. Lymphocytic aggregates with noncaseating granulomas suggest granulomatous gastritis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and endoscopy findings suggest gastric cancer. Among the options, gland-forming cuboidal cells are most likely to be seen on histologic examination of a gastric biopsy specimen from a cancerous lesion in the stomach.

We refer to a medical textbook for help. The presentation and location of the lesion suggest gastric adenocarcinoma. The most common type of gastric adenocarcinoma is intestinal type, which is characterized by gland-forming cuboidal cells. Option A is characteristic of acute gastritis, option B is characteristic of chronic gastritis, and option D is characteristic of granulomatous gastritis, which are not likely diagnoses for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is suggestive of gastric cancer, and among the options, gland-forming cuboidal cells are most likely to be seen in adenocarcinoma of the stomach. Neutrophilic infiltration with pit abscesses are seen in acute gastritis, foveolar and smooth muscle hyperplasia are seen in chronic atrophic gastritis, and lymphocytic aggregates with noncaseating granulomas are seen in sarcoidosis or Crohn’s disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest gastric cancer, with the positive stool test indicating possible bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract. The histologic examination of a gastric biopsy specimen from the lesion is most likely to show gland-forming cuboidal cells, which are characteristic of adenocarcinoma, the most common type of gastric cancer. The other options are not typically associated with gastric cancer.

The most likely histologic examination finding in this case is gland-forming cuboidal cells, which are indicative of adenocarcinoma of the stomach. Option A describes gastritis, while options B and D are not typically associated with gastric cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical picture suggests gastric cancer, and the raised lesion with central ulceration on the lesser curvature of the stomach is a common location for it to occur. Histologic examination of gastric cancer often shows gland-forming cuboidal cells, which is the most likely answer option. Neutrophilic infiltration with pit abscesses suggests peptic ulcer disease, foveolar and smooth muscle hyperplasia suggest gastritis, and lymphocytic aggregates with noncaseating granulomas suggest Crohn's disease.
